title: 90% of rocket fuel is used to propel the rocket to stratosphere altitude. Can't we just make a huge helium balloon or airship, fly to stratosphere and launch a smaller rocket from there? - Quora

response.answer_text: Launching from the stratosphere is an idea that has been around for some time, and if you look up Stratolaunch, they are indeed building an aircraft (completed, but not flown, by now) that will attempt to launch rockets from a higher altitude to save propellant. It will not save 90% since a large part of that propellant is required to achieve a velocity high enough to reach orbit, but it will save some fuel to overcome the massive drag in the lower atmosphere (and could potentially make the structure of the launcher lighter since the loads at “max q” or maximum dynamic pressure are less). Other solutions are the ones that Virgin Galactic are working on for example, where you essentially have a hybrid between an aircraft and a rocket which can fly to a sufficient altitude to overcome most of the drag efficiently and then turn on the rocket engines and build up the velocity to reach orbit. The idea of a giant balloon/airship is an interesting one, however I’m sure there’s a good reason that nobody has attempted it. Or is there…?

Your premise is incorrect. About 10% of the fuel is used to reach orbital altitude. The other 90% is used to accelerate to orbital velocity. Launching from the height a balloon could reach - which is still significantly lower than orbital altitude - wouldn’t save more than a few percent of the rocket size. There have been some experimental projects to launch rockets from balloons. The concept is known as a ‘Rockoon’. It doesn’t save much fuel, and the additional difficulty and expense of the balloon means it’s rarely worth doing.

As the other answers have said, the issue is developing the velocity needed to go into Earth orbit. This is why a high fuel mass is required. Your idea has been around for quite awhile. Here is video from the 1950’s where a rocket was launched from high altitude using a ballon. Note that the rocket here was a simple up-down flight. It didn’t go into orbit.  Note the relative sizes between the balloon and the rocket. A rocket large enough to put a significant payload in orbit would need a balloon of impracticable size. A Stratolaunch type aircraft is a much better idea.

It is not correct that 90% of fuel is used to get to stratospheric altitude. The vast majority of the fuel is used to give the rocket orbital speed, 17,000 mph. The number is closer to,the other way round = only about 10% is used to get to stratospheric altitude. Launching from up in the air would be a huge increase in complexity, adding more bits to go wrong. And you still have the problem of getting the airship down once it has launched - you would probably have to vent a huge amount of expensive helium.

Even the upper stage of a rocket weighs several tons worth of fuel and steel to host the rocket engine. A helium-balloon merely floats on top of the nitrogen-/oxygen-atmosphere.So being burdened with the tanks of liquified hydrogen and oxygen neccessary to produce the thrust needed to eventually leave earth's field of gravity the average balloon would not make it to the stratosphere.Now, just because man-carrying balloons are pretty large-size vehicles, actually, "huge" would have to be several orders of mangnitude larger than those.

We have been doing that since the early days of supersonic flight. For tomorrow’s launches, look to the Stratolaunch by Microsoft co founder Paul Allen. Home Page - Stratolaunch  Balloons and airships are fantasy stuff. Real men use the Stratolaunch!! lol

That's not quite true. Yes, most of it is burned before it gets into space, but it's not about going up that far, but sideways really fast.  Also, fuel isn't the expensive part. It's building the rocket in the first place. But yes, the idea of using balloons has been around for quite a while. It has just never been worth the extra complexity.
